Authors:
Vanessa Nascimento Brito, Kaliane Sirio Araújo, Tiago de
Souza Leite, Janaina Lana Alves, Casley Borges Queiroz, Olinto L.
Pereira, Marisa Vieira de Queiroz
Title:
Endophytic Trichoderma species from rubber trees native to
the Brazilian Amazon Forest, including four new species
Keywords:
DNA barcoding; Hypocreales; GCPSR; Phylogeny;
Taxonomy
Abstract:
Fungi belonging to the genus Trichoderma have been widely
recognized as efficient controllers of phytopathogens. Although the
majority of isolates currently deployed in biocontrol have been isolated
from the soil, endophytic Trichoderma spp. are considered a promising
option for application in biocontrol. In this study, 30 endophytic fungi
isolated from the leaves, stems, and roots of Hevea spp. Forest were
analyzed by molecular data using specific DNA barcodes: the genes
encoding translation elongation factor 1-α (tef1-α), and the second
largest subunit of RNA polymerase II (rpb2). Genealogical Concordance
Phylogenetic Species Recognition criteria (GCPSR) were used for the
recognition of species. The phylogenetics analysis showed the occurrence
of several species such as T. erinaceum, T. ovalisporum, T. koningiosis,
T. sparsum, T. lentiforme, T. virens and T. spirale and overtime targets
of later research. The molecular and morphological features resulted in
the discovery of four new species, namely, T. acreanum sp. nov., T.
ararianum sp. nov., T. endoviride sp. nov. and T. brasiliensis sp. nov.
which were strongly supported by a posteriori probability values.
Bayesian phylograms supported the placement of T. acreanum and T.
ararianum as a sister group to T. koningiopsis; T. endoviride as T.
subviride and T. brasiliensis as T. brevicompactum. Identification of
new occurrences and the taxa of the genus Trichoderma in tropical plants
may not only not only reveal new potential agents for the control of
phytopathogens but also improve our understanding of the diversity of
Trichoderma in a wide variety of substrates of a tropical tree.
